data.title: Who was Nelly Sachs? Google Doodle honours poet who escaped Nazi Germany
data.meta_description: Nelly Sachs fled Nazi Germany as a refugee to Sweden during World War II and shared her experiences in a series of poignant poetry
data.text:
German-Swedish poet and playwright Nelly Sachs was born 127 years ago.

The anniversary of her birth is marked today with a special Google Doodle.

She is know for her poetry collections including In the Houses of Death (1946), Eclipse of Stars (1949), And No One Knows Where to Go (1957), Flight and Metamorphosis (1959) and for the play Eli (1951).

Nelly Sachs fled Nazi Germany as a refugee to Sweden during World War II and her experiences made her a poignant spokeswoman for the trauma of her fellow Jews.

Leonie 'Nelly' Sachs was born into a Jewish family in Berlin on December 10, 1891. She studied dance and literature as a child, but due to her frail health she was discouraged from the former and nurtured with the later.

She began writing as a teenager, composing romantic verse aged 17.

Nelly Sachs published her poetry in German periodicals as well as a collection of stories called Legends and Tales.

Escaping Nazi Germany

Her father Georg William Sachs died in 1930 and Nelly and her mother Margarete were forced to flee Germany for Sweden in 1940.

They were helped by distinguished Swedish writer Selma Lagerlöf when their apartment was torn apart by the Gestapo who interrogated them.

They were scheduled to report to a concentration camp within a week, but luckily Lagerlöf helped them.

She corresponded with Lagerlöf—who became the first woman to win the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1909— who saved Sachs’ and her mother’s lives.

Lagerlöf petitioned the Swedish royal family to help the Sachs escape Germany at the start of World War II.

Nelly was so scared at one point she lost her voice.

Nelly Sachs and her mother

After escaping to Sweden as a refugee, Sachs supported herself and her mother in a one-room apartment by working as a translator.

She lived in Stockholm for the rest of her life. She learnt the language and became a citizen in 1952.

During this time, she wrote powerful poems and plays about the aftermath of the war and family members who died in concentration camps.

She suffered a series of breakdowns after her mother died in 1950. She was continually tormented by visions of persecution.

Nelly Sachs' poetry

Her haunting poem “O die Schornsteine" ("O the Chimneys"), evokes the spirits of the dearly departed through the image of smoke rising from the camps.

Sachs described the “metaphors” in her poetry as “wounds,” but her work also explores themes of transformation and forgiveness.

She expanded on these ideas in her best-known play Eli: Ein Mysterienspiel vom Leiden Israels (Eli: A Mystery Play of the Sufferings of Israel), written in 1951.

Winning the Nobel-Peace Prize

Sachs was awarded the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1966. She also won many other accolades including the 1965 Peace Prize of the German Book Trade.

“In spite of all the horrors of the past,” she said when accepting the award. “I believe in you.”

Nelly Sachs' death

Sachs died from intestinal cancer in Stockholm, Sweden, on May 12, 1970, aged 78.

Her most famous poem is ‘O Die Schornsteine’ which translates as O the Chimneys.

‘O Die Schornsteine’ (1967)

O the chimneys

On the carefully planned dwellings of death

When Israel’s body rose dissolved in smoke

Through the air –

To be welcomed by a chimney sweep star

Turned black

Or was it a ray of the sun?

O the chimneys!

Paths of freedom for the dust of Jeremiah and Job –

Who dreamed you up and built stone upon stone

The path of smoke for their flight?

O dwellings of death

Set out so enticingly

For the host of the house, who used to be the guest –

O you fingers

Laying the stone of the threshold

Like a knife between life and death –

O you chimneys

O you fingers

And Israel’s body dissolves in smoke through the air!
